title: Boost Your Well-being With 3 Proven Benefits Of Ginseng
author: Aditya Birla Health Insurance
description: Do you want to know how adding ginseng can transform your life? Discover the remarkable benefits of ginseng nd enhance overall well-being.
cleaned_text: Ginseng is a medicinal herb that is high in antioxidant content. It is a small plant that contains fleshy roots. It is well known for boosting your brain function, immune system, blood sugar levels, etc. This herb has been used for centuries, and the health benefits of ginseng remain relevant even today. What you need to know: Types of ginseng Most of the ginseng plants belong to the Panax genus species. Here are some of the different types of ginseng: - White ginseng: You can find white ginseng in America. It is usually peeled and air-dried. These types of ginseng are bleached under the sun to turn their root into a yellowish-white color. However, some people prefer air drying the ginseng to retain the vital nutrients and components. - Red Ginseng: This type of ginseng is often peeled, heated at 100Celsius, and sun-dried. It is a herbal brew that enhances your overall well-being. Red ginseng is often found more than white ginseng. - Indian Ginseng: Indian ginseng, also known as Ashwagandha, is one of the most important herbs in Ayurveda. It has been used for centuries for its several health benefits. It can help elevate your state of mind and make you happier. The health benefits of ginseng consumption daily can keep the following health complications at bay: - Heart complications - Hepatitis C [High blood pressure](https://www.adityabirlacapital.com/healthinsurance/active-together/2020/08/10/how-to-control-high-blood-pressure-with-bananas/) - Tiredness Health benefits of ginseng Consume it daily to reap the health benefits of ginseng: - Features anti-inflammatory properties: Ginseng features a lot of beneficial anti-inflammatories and antioxidant properties. Ginseng contains ginsenoside compounds, which are responsible for reducing oxidative damage and curb inflammation. This helps in reducing the risk of getting affected by chronic health conditions. Another health benefit of ginseng is it can reduce muscle damage and inflammation caused due to exercising. In addition, consuming ginseng lowers your [stress levels](https://www.adityabirlacapital.com/healthinsurance/active-together/2022/11/03/what-are-the-7-ways-in-which-you-can-manage-stress-eating/) and improves your mental state. Red ginseng can help increase the antioxidant enzyme activity levels, decreasing oxidative stress. - Enhances brain function: Ginseng is also responsible for enhancing your cognitive abilities, like memory, mood, and behaviors. Ginseng is rich in compound K, which can protect your nervous system against free radicals. Consuming ginseng can also help in managing [depression and anxiety.](https://www.adityabirlacapital.com/healthinsurance/active-together/2022/06/28/yoga-encourages-self-care-strategies-that-can-help-you-with-anxiety-and-depression/) - Helps in lowering blood sugar levels: Ginseng can lower the blood sugar levels of individuals who are diagnosed or free from diabetes. Another one of the health benefits of ginseng consumption is that it can help enhance your pancreatic cell function and boost insulin production. It can also stabilize your blood sugar, increase hemoglobin count and involve insulin sensitivity in people with [type-2 diabetes](https://www.adityabirlacapital.com/healthinsurance/active-together/2021/12/17/7-best-and-worst-foods-for-an-indian-type-2-diabetes-diet/). How to use ginseng? Ginseng can be consumed in several ways. However, you should consult with your doctor before incorporating it into your diet. Here are some of them: - Ginseng root extract can be mixed with juices and drinks. - You can boil the ginseng root to make tea. - You can boil dried ginseng root to create a potent extract. - You can also go for ginseng capsules and powders. When consumed regularly, ginseng can promote your overall well-being. Consuming ginseng benefits in managing cholesterol, blood sugar levels and immunity.
